title: About me
text:
https://www.linkedin.com/in/weifan-wu-78604a162/

Basic information
Hello everyone, my name is Weifan Wu. I am currently a third-year Ph.D.¬†student in food science and technology. My focus is about antimicrobial activity of pomegranate against common foodborne pathogens. Welcome to connect me on Linkedin!üòÑ


Statistical experience
I was first exposed to statistics due to the requirement of program of study, however, I have gradually developed deep interest in statistical analysis, especially when it‚Äôs applied to data in public health area. The statistics courses I have taken include experimental design, applied data analysis using SPSS, spatial epidemiology. Last year, I independently accomplished a spatial analysis of association of race and age with COVID-19 incidence rates on the county-level in Georgia using Bayesian spatial hierarchical generalized Linear model and disease mapping. I also use SAS to conduct basic statistics analysis (general linear model, pearson‚Äôs r) for my own research project. Therefore, I have knowledge of statistics and some experience with data analysis using softwares such as R, SPSS, SAS. Since my interests mainly lie with public health data , I would like to gain more in-depth experience with handling real-world public health data using R, which is something that I am looking forward to getting from this course.ü•≥


Fun fact about me
my eyebrows can dance!ü§£


Unknown facts about data science
The attached linked is about 7 surprising facts about data science. The most striking fact is that less than 0.5% of all data we create is ever analysed and used.
https://www.lewagon.com/blog/data-science-facts

title: data analysis exercise
text:
#data description This data set was found on data.cdc.gov. The data set contains the information regarding the reported botulism cases, a national notifiable disease, reported in the United states. There are five variables presented in the header: State, Year, BotType (the type of transmission), ToxinType (the type of toxin), and Count (reported cases)
#Setup load packages
#data loading
#checking data
#data cleaning after checking the data, R consider the numbers under Year as regular numbers (double), so we need to change it to character; Also, I consider Count as the outcome of interest, ToxinType & BotType might associate with the outcome in certain way. I am also interested in the spread of botulism-infection cases in the states and in different years.

After looking at the variables, the interesting questions I could think of include 1.Is there any pattern of age difference throughout the years (e.g.¬†increasing age difference as time goes by)? 2. Are males always older than females as Hollywood couples? 3. Is there any same-gender couple with age difference? 4. Is age difference associated with directors (preference). 5. Which actors (actresses) always play characters who are involved in romantic relationships with age gap? Since the column names are clean, the data structure seems correct, and there is no missing value, it seems like the author who cleaned this data did a good job. We can start to explore some data For now, let‚Äôs try to answer the first by selecting the related variables exploratory data analysis report

#first, let's explore age difference by years
ggscatterstats(data=age_gaps,x=release_year,y=age_difference,type="np") #it seems like as time goes by, the age gap significantly decreases, let see if there are difference between genders (male is older v.s. female is older)

  geom_point(size=3,alpha=0.7)+
  geom_line(linewidth=1.5,show.legend=FALSE)+
  labs(title="Divorce Rates By 
Education",
       subtitle="Ages 35 to 44",
       x=NULL,y=NULL)+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks=seq(1960,2012,by=10),labels=c("1960","'70","'80","'90","2000","'10"),minor_breaks=NULL)+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks=seq(0,25,by=5),labels=c("0","5","10","15","20","25%"),minor_breaks=NULL)+
  scale_color_manual(breaks=c("High school or less","Some College","College graduates"),values=c("#6699CC","#0047AB","#89CFF0"))+
  theme(
        text=element_text(size=16),
        plot.title=element_textbox_simple(size=14,face="bold"),#control the size of title and subtitle
        plot.subtitle=element_textbox_simple(size=12),
        plot.background = element_rect(fill="#ededed"),#change the whole plot background color
        panel.background=element_rect(fill="#ededed"),#change the panel background color
        panel.grid.major = element_line(color="lightgrey"), #change the grid color in the panel background
        legend.position="none",
        axis.text=element_text(size=12), #specify the text size
        axis.ticks=element_blank()       #remove all the ticks
        )+
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0)+ #highlight the x axis (when y=0)
  annotate("text",x=1995, y=7,label="High school or less")+ #using annotate functions to add text and lines in the graph
  annotate("text",x=1995,y=22,label="Some college")+
  annotate("text",x=2005,y=14,label="College graduate")+
  annotate("segment",x=1990,xend=1990,y=7,yend=16,color="black",size=0.7)+
  annotate("segment",x=1995,xend=1995,y=21,yend=17,color="black",size=0.7)+
  annotate("segment",x=2005,xend=2005,y=13,yend=10,color="black",size=0.7)+
  coord_fixed(ratio=2, ylim=c(0,25),xlim=c(1960,2012))    #control the ratio of y/x coordinate, but also specify the limits for y&x axis in case this function overwrite the axis range

title: data analysis exercise
text:
#data description This data set was found on data.cdc.gov. The data set contains the information regarding the reported botulism cases, a national notifiable disease, reported in the United states. There are five variables presented in the header: State, Year, BotType (the type of transmission), ToxinType (the type of toxin), and Count (reported cases)
#Setup load packages

library(readr)#for loading csv file
library(here)#to set relative paths

here() starts at C:/Users/weifa/OneDrive/Documents/GitKraken/MADA/data analysis/Weifan-MADA-portfolio

library(dplyr)#for data processing and cleaning

The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(skimr)#for browsing data
library(forcats)#for processing categorical data

#data loading

botulism=read_csv(data_location)

What are the types of botulism found in this dataset?

processedData %>% pull(BotType) %>% unique()

[1] Foodborne Infant    Wound     Other    
Levels: Foodborne Infant Wound Other


What type of botulism was the most prevalent from 2000-2017

#Create table of the sums of the count column based on conditions 
botulism_2000s =  data.frame (BotType  = c("Foodborn", "Infant", "Wound", "other"),
                  Total = c(sum(processedData[which(processedData$BotType=='Foodborne'), 5]), sum(processedData[which(processedData$BotType=='Infant'), 5]),sum(processedData[which(processedData$BotType=='Wound'), 5]),sum(processedData[which(processedData$BotType=='Other'), 5]))
                  )
botulism_2000s

   BotType Total
1 Foodborn   344
2   Infant  1972
3    Wound   386
4    other    52


Infant is the most prevalent type of botulism from 2000-2017. Followed by wound and foodborne.
What is the prevalence of the types each year?

#Plot Botulism types
botulism_plot = ggplot(processedData, aes(fill=BotType, y=Count, x=Year)) + 
    geom_bar(position="dodge", stat="identity")+scale_x_date(date_breaks = "1 year", date_labels = "%Y")+theme(legend.position = "bottom",axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10, angle=60, hjust=1))+ggtitle("Types of Botulism Cases between 2000 and 2017")+theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

botulism_plot




What toxins are leading in infant botulism?

Infant = processedData %>% filter(BotType == "Infant", Year >='2000-01-01' )

#Plot Foodborn Botulism 
infant_plot = ggplot(Infant, aes(fill=ToxinType, y=Count, x=Year)) + 
    geom_bar(position="dodge", stat="identity")+scale_x_date(date_breaks = "1 year", date_labels = "%Y")+theme(legend.position = "bottom",axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10, angle=60, hjust=1))+ggtitle("Infant Botulism types for 2000-2017")+theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

infant_plot




The most prominent toxin type in infant botulism between 2000 and 2017 is toxin A
